awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Compact Object Mergers in the Era of Multi-Messenger Astrophysics
awd_abstract_narration:
The era of gravitational wave astronomy began a few years ago with the first direct detections by the LIGO/Virgo collaboration. These detections and the accompanying understanding result from detailed knowledge of expected gravitational waveforms, and numerical evolutions are a critical ingredient in this regard. This project studies a primary source of gravitational waves for the recently upgraded LIGO detectors, namely the merger and inspiral of neutron stars. The merger of binary neutron stars is also responsible for concurrent electromagnetic signals to which conventional telescopes are sensitive, so called multi-messenger astronomy. Simulations will be carried out to study both expectations for gravitational and electromagnetic signals.

Various aspects of such mergers will be studied in detail. For example, phase transitions within the neutron stars may affect expected signals during the merger. Using a piecewise-polytrope to model the equation of state with and without a phase transition, evolutions will reveal possible differences. Other effects to be studied include multiscale approximations of magnetic instabilities and axion clouds. These studies will prove helpful not only to the gravitational wave data analysis community but to the astronomical community as well. The activities described here will help further undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral research and STEM training, including a number of underrepresented individuals (continuing an existing record of such mentoring).  Also, this work builds on open-source infrastructure and other open-source tools, and thus it helps support broadly useful, publicly released, software.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award has supported research into astrophysical systems with incredibly strong gravity that potentially can be observed with gravitational waves or light or possibly both. Much of this work involves the computational modeling of the merger of one neutron star with another precisely because this system offers the best chances of observing in both gravitational and light waves, so called multi-messenger astronomy. The event GW170817 was precisely such a merger and it was observed by the world's gravitational wave detectors and followed closely by most of the conventional telescopes that observe electromagnetic waves (in other words, light). More such observations are expected and further theoretical work offers the potential to extract the most science possible from them.


More particularly, the research enabled by this award focused on both binary neutron stars and binaries with at least one black hole. We have developed a new code, MHDuet, that can take advantage of the latest supercomputers and model the strong gravity coupled to the matter that forms neutron stars. We used this code to study the effects of phase transitions in this matter occurring within magnetized neutron stars.  This code will be the workhorse for future studies and for extensions to include the physics of neutrinos.


We also studied a couple alternatives to the conventional theory of gravity. Although Einstein's theory of gravity has passed every test applied to it, it remains possible that an alternative will be found that works better. More likely, explorations of alternatives will further boost our confidences in Einstein's theory. One such alternative is Einstein-Maxwell-dilaton, and our study of binary black hole mergers in the theory found differences that might potentially be observed in gravitational waves some day.  Yet another alternative is motivated by the quest to develop a quantum theory of gravity.  Using a "polymerized" model of gravity, we studied the threshold for black hole formation and found subtle differences compared to predictions for Einstein's theory.
